prompt: Facts: The appellant, Kans Raj, was married to Jasbir Kaur (deceased) approximately 1.5 years before the incident.; Incident occurred on the night between July 23-24, 1992, at the matrimonial home.; Jasbir Kaur sustained 100% burn injuries.; She was initially taken to Civil Hospital, Faridkot, and later moved to CMC Hospital, Ludhiana.; First Dying Declaration (Ex. PK): Recorded by ASI Surjit Singh at Civil Hospital, Faridkot, around 1:30 AM on July 24, 1992. Jasbir Kaur stated her husband (appellant) poured kerosene on her and set her ablaze after a quarrel.; Second Dying Declaration (Ex. PL): Recorded by Shri R.L. Anand, Judicial Magistrate First Class, Faridkot, at 3:05 AM on July 24, 1992, at Civil Hospital, Faridkot. Similar content to the first declaration, implicating the husband.; Third Dying Declaration (Ex. PB): Recorded by ASI Niranjan Singh at CMC Hospital, Ludhiana, on July 24, 1992, at 10:15 PM. Again implicated the husband for pouring kerosene and setting her on fire.; Medical Evidence: Dr. P.S. Dhaliwal (PW1) certified Jasbir Kaur fit to make the first statement (Ex. PK/A). Dr. Ajit Singh Chahal (PW2) certified fitness for the second statement (Ex. PL/A). Dr. Harjinder Singh (PW7) from CMC Ludhiana noted she was conscious and oriented when admitted and certified fitness for the third statement (Ex. PB/B). Post-mortem (Dr. Gurdip Singh Sethi, PW6) confirmed death due to shock from 100% burns.; Witness Testimonies: Parents of the deceased (PW3 Harbans Singh, PW4 Mohinder Kaur) testified about prior dowry demands (scooter, cash) and harassment.; Defense Plea: Appellant claimed Jasbir Kaur committed suicide due to depression over not having conceived a child. He claimed he tried to save her and sustained burn injuries himself.; Trial Court: Convicted the appellant under Section 302 IPC and sentenced him to life imprisonment.; High Court: Dismissed the appeal, upholding the Trial Court's conviction and sentence.; Supreme Court: Appeal filed against the High Court judgment. | IPC: Section 302 (Murder), Section 304B (Dowry Death) - Discussed as alternative, Section 498A (Cruelty by Husband or Relatives) - Discussed contextually, Section 306 (Abetment of Suicide) - Discussed as defense alternative
